content: AI arrived just in time to offset shrinking workforces and decades of weak productivity, and it fixes the economic math rather than breaking it.
Jobs don't disappear due to AI; instead, tasks shift, and AI amplifies differences by making good people better and great people unusually effective.
The winning strategy in an AI-driven economy is the talent stack: combine multiple top 25% skills plus commercialization, because rarity comes from overlap, not being the best at one thing.

For roughly 50 years, real economic progress has underperformed historical norms, with productivity growth falling well below postwar levels and declining birth rates, indicating that the economic math stopped working.
AI is not a threat to human work but a lever that reshapes it.
Stacking complementary skills, rather than chasing singular mastery, is the most reliable way to stay valuable in an AI-driven economy.
Jobs are bundles of tasks, and tasks are fluid; when technology changes, tasks move, but jobs survive longer than any single task inside them.
AI accelerates the process of tasks shifting within jobs.
Panic about mass job loss misses the point because when population shrinks and productivity rises together, remaining human labor becomes more valuable, not less, due to scarcity.
AI magnifies differences among individuals, making good people better and great people unusually effective, thus widening the gap.
The 'talent stack' is an individual strategy for an AI-driven economy, involving becoming very good (top 25%) at multiple things rather than trying to be the best in the world at a single thing.
Rarity comes from the overlap of multiple skills, not from dominance in a single skill.

The talent stack has two layers: 'cornerstone' skills that define output (e.g., writing + humor, engineering + systems thinking, design + taste) and 'commercialization' skills that turn output into leverage (e.g., business literacy, distribution, work ethic, risk tolerance).
Capitalism rewards things that are rare and valuable, and individuals become rare by combining skills that rarely coexist.
AI dramatically lowers the cost of combining skills, making adjacent skills like coding, writing, analysis, and design more accessible, thus collapsing the barrier to stacking.
The future does not belong to narrow specialists defending titles but to people who deliberately build combinations of skills.
